docs.snippet: and then, perhaps, just the slightest bit pleased with myself, when nothing ''bad'' happened.   Until this morning. The alarm didn't go off. I got mascara in my eye. Black coffee spilled on my white blouse. I got stuck in my elevator. I missed my ...
docs.lead_paragraph: and then, perhaps, just the slightest bit pleased with myself, when nothing ''bad'' happened. Until this morning. The alarm didn't go off. I got mascara in my eye. Black coffee spilled on my white blouse. I got stuck in my elevator. I missed my bus.

docs.snippet: John Jay Hooker, new chairman of the board of United Press International, says he obtained a 30 percent interest in the nation's second largest news agency last week with virtually no outlay in money.   Mr. Hooker, a former politician and publishe...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Jay Hooker, new chairman of the board of United Press International, says he obtained a 30 percent interest in the nation's second largest news agency last week with virtually no outlay in money. Mr. Hooker, a former politician and publisher in Tennessee, said in an interview this week that he acquired the stock for ''$1 and other valuable considerations'' after two of the four men who bought the ailing service from E.@W. Scripps Company last June relinquished their shares. The ''other considerations'' were described as his extensive contacts in the journalistic, political, entertainment and financial communities and his ability to obtain funds, if necessary, for continued operation of the news service till its losses could be overcome. Mr. Hooker's statements amounted to additional indications that Scripps turned over the news service to four new owners last year for little more than an assumption of pension obligations. All but Gave It Away, One Says One source said this week that Scripps all but gave away the news service in the original transaction. Another source, at Media News Corporation of Nashville, the new parent company of U.@P.@I., said Len R. Small and Cordell J. Overgaard, the two directors who returned their shares, which the company then passed on to Mr. Hooker, had made ''only an insignificant investment'' of money and received no payment when they returned their shares.

headline.main: U.P.I. OWNERSHIP TRANSFERS SEEM TO INVOLVE LITTLE CASH

byline.original: By WENDELL RAWLS Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A Federal jury found Jamiel Chagra not guilty today of plotting the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., but convicted him on two lesser charges.   Mr. Chagra, who is serving 30 years for drug dealing, was acquitted of murder ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal jury found Jamiel Chagra not guilty today of plotting the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., but convicted him on two lesser charges. Mr. Chagra, who is serving 30 years for drug dealing, was acquitted of murder and conspiracy to commit murder. He was convicted of conspiracy to obstruct justice and conspiracy to possess more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana with intent to sell.

headline.main: GAMBLER IS ACQUITTED OF PLOTTING ASSASSINATION OF A FEDERAL JUDGE

docs.snippet: WHEN Margaret Mead went to Samoa in 1925 to study adolescence, she was 23 years old and possessed with a vision of the dominant role of culture in human behavior. Anthropology was then passing through its own adolescence, struggling with conflicti...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Margaret Mead went to Samoa in 1925 to study adolescence, she was 23 years old and possessed with a vision of the dominant role of culture in human behavior. Anthropology was then passing through its own adolescence, struggling with conflicting ideologies and suffering from inexperience. In the Victorian view, biology, or human nature, was considered the decisive factor in determining differences of behavior. This was interpreted in ways that seemed to underpin ideas of racial and class superiority. But a reaction to the movement had emerged under the leadership of Franz Boas, the celebrated Columbia University anthropologist and mentor of Margaret Mead.

headline.main: CUSTOMS CHECK: LEAVE YOUR IDEOLOGICAL BAGGAGE BEHIND

docs.snippet: IN its struggle to secure a foothold in the regional theater firmament, Stamford's Hartman Theater may be reversing a stereotype, and devising a new strategy for survival.   Generally, new plays mean high risk; classics and revivals are considered...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN its struggle to secure a foothold in the regional theater firmament, Stamford's Hartman Theater may be reversing a stereotype, and devising a new strategy for survival. Generally, new plays mean high risk; classics and revivals are considered to be the crowd pleasers. However, there has been a paucity of original home-grown plays on Broadway where the theater season is, by critical consensus, grim as well as sparse. ''Broadway has become more geared to event presentation, as opposed to plays,'' the Hartman's executive director, Harris Goldman, said. ''Besides, our community, which is close to New York, has become accustomed to new plays and they look forward to them. We can't thrive on classics alone,'' he added.

headline.main: HARTMAN PLOTS COURSE WITH NEW WORKS

docs.snippet: WHAT looked good last week?  Not quite a million things, but almost, starting with the beaded e vening sweater Yves Saint Laurent paired with a long crepe skirt in h is spring couture collection in Paris. After two years of u nremitting ball gowns...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT looked good last week? Not quite a million things, but almost, starting with the beaded e vening sweater Yves Saint Laurent paired with a long crepe skirt in h is spring couture collection in Paris. After two years of u nremitting ball gowns from anyone who ever hoped to be a designer, t hat simple sweater and skirt looked like the most modern way to d ress at night. Better still, it seems to be pointing a new direction. Geoffrey Beene showed a similar beaded sweater, with full trousers, last October in his spring ready-to-wear collection. Did Saint Laurent get his idea from Beene? Was this another example of trans-Atlantic cross-pollination? Perhaps, but even though Beene was first, his sweater was baggy at best, covered with over-large sequins in enormous flower patterns. It took Saint Laurent to make the look trim and new, and to prove what a little sequin, no flower, can do.

docs.snippet: Nominations for the 1982 Directors Guild of America award were announced Sunday and contained one major surprise.  The surprise nominee was Wolfgang Petersen for ''Das Boot'' (''The Boat''), a German-language movie about a U-boat crew during the f...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nominations for the 1982 Directors Guild of America award were announced Sunday and contained one major surprise. The surprise nominee was Wolfgang Petersen for ''Das Boot'' (''The Boat''), a German-language movie about a U-boat crew during the final months of World War II. The last foreign-language nominee for the guild award was Lina Wertmuller for ''Seven Beauties'' in 1976. Mr. Petersen had not been labeled a likely contender. ''Das Boot'' was released in America by Triumph, the classics division of Columbia Pictures.

docs.snippet: year-old former hod carrier with no great love for boxing but an admiration for fighters with ''character,'' has been preparing to take the world middleweight title from Marvelous Marvin Hagler.   Tony Sibson, in his blue-collar fantasies, would r...
docs.lead_paragraph: year-old former hod carrier with no great love for boxing but an admiration for fighters with ''character,'' has been preparing to take the world middleweight title from Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Tony Sibson, in his blue-collar fantasies, would rather be the lead guitar player in his own band than the middleweight champion of the world. But the guitar he has owned for six years sits quietly in his Leicestershire home while he keeps working toward his Feb. 11 appointment with Hagler. ''This is fate, I believe in fate,'' said Sibson as he put on a sweat suit near one of the gas heaters in the cold gymnasium. ''I never dreamed I'd be British champion or Commonwealth champion or European champion.''

docs.snippet: Eight Peruvian journalists were ambushed and killed by a band of Andean peasants who mistook them for leftist guerrillas, the military command announced today.   The command said police and army patrols had unearthed the bodies of all eight journa...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight Peruvian journalists were ambushed and killed by a band of Andean peasants who mistook them for leftist guerrillas, the military command announced today. The command said police and army patrols had unearthed the bodies of all eight journalists who were killed last week in the village of Uchuraccay, about 220 miles southeast of Lima. President Fernando Belaunde Terry called for a minute of silence at his weekly news conference today for the slain journalists. He said the peasants apparently thought they were about to be attacked themselves.

headline.main: 8 NEWSMEN IN PERU, MISTAKEN FOR REBELS, ARE SLAIN IN AMBUSH
